Headline.Para: The Freeze and Thaw That Give Us Maple Syrup; It's the sweet season for tapping trees—but not every maple is able

LeadPara.Para: Maple syrup is possibly my favorite breakfast treat—a drizzle of gold that turns my morning granola and yogurt into something special. The critical season for producing it is right now, with sap trickling out of maple trees from Kentucky to Canada.

But collecting sap is a frustrating business. Even major producers can't be sure of the size or timing of their harvest. The uncertainty results from the subtle hydraulic architecture inside the trees, which I find almost as beautiful as the syrup itself.

TailParas.Para: We have maple syrup only because these trees do something very unusual when they repeatedly freeze and thaw. The tappers are waiting for days when it goes below freezing at night but warms up to about 40 degrees Fahrenheit during the day. Their role is to drill a hole about two inches into the tree, attach a tap and wait. But the real action is happening just under the bark, in delicate internal pipework far too small for us to see.

Maple sap flows through the tree's water-transport system, called the xylem, inside minuscule vertical tubes about a thousandth of an inch in diameter. These tubes are surrounded by even thinner fibers filled with air. The sap transport relies on water waltzing back and forth between the main pipework and these airy side fibers.

The dance starts as the sun goes down and the tree begins to freeze. Water can go through the thin wall between the main tubes and their associated fibers, but sugar can't. As the tree starts to freeze, pure water seeps out of the sap and into the fibers. But this pure water freezes more easily than the sugary sap, because the sugar acts like antifreeze. The fiber becomes a store for frozen water, filling up with ice as more liquid water seeps in.

The tree takes in water from its roots to keep the main tubes full. But as the temperature drops further, even the sap has to freeze, and the tree becomes a giant popsicle. The main pipes are filled with frozen sugary sap, and the fibers are filled with pure frozen water. Everything is cold and still until the sun rises.

As the sun's heat percolates through the bark, the pipework starts to thaw. The sap melts first, becoming liquid again. But the extra water from the roots hasn't gone away. So when the pure water in the fibers starts to melt and pushes back to join the rest of the sap, there's no room for it. The pressure in the sap rises, because the sap is being squeezed, and if there's a tap in the tree, sap oozes out, pushed by the pressure behind it. Sap will run for a few hours, until the excess pressure has gone. The next night, the cycle starts again.

Without the freeze-thaw cycle, there's no pressure to push the sap out of the tree. In some years, these cycles happen very early in the season, even in January, and sometimes they don't start until mid-March. In a good year, there might be four to six weeks of freeze/thaw days, and a single mature tree could produce 15 gallons of sap (enough for a half gallon of syrup). The exact timing has varied a lot in the past few years, as weather patterns have shifted.

There are big, healthy sugar maples in my own neighborhood park in London, but I won't be expecting any syrup from them; they're purely decorative. It's never cold enough in the U.K. to get the right temperature cycles. My breakfast thoughts turn instead to those vast chilly trees elsewhere—and the delicate physics that my morning treat relies on.
